name: Daniel C. Dennett
contribution: For contributions to foundational problems in artificial intelligence and the philosophy of mind.

name: Thomas Glen Dietterich
contribution: For contributions to the science and practice of machine learning, methodology of machine learning research, and for service to the AI community.

name: John S. Gero
contribution: For pioneering research on AI in architecture and engineering, and outstanding leadership in the AI in design research community.

name: Julia B. Hirschberg
contribution: For foundational research in discourse and speech processing; and for pioneering development of algorithms for incorporating discourse-level intonational features into speech synthesis systems.

name: Jim Howe
contribution: For contributions to the design of learning environments, AI technology transfer, and the promotion of AI research in the United Kingdom.

name: Philip Klahr
contribution: For applying AI technology to solve real business problems, and for service to the AI community.

name: Richard E. Korf
contribution: For contributions to the development and analysis of heuristic search methods.

name: Kathleen R. McKeown
contribution: For contributions to natural language generation and integration of language and graphics.

name: Jacques Pitrat
contribution: For his roles as a pioneer of AI in France, outstanding teacher and student leader; and for his many valuable contributions involving metaknowledge.

name: Zenon W. Pylyshyn
contribution: For sustained contributions to the foundations of artificial intelligence and cognitive science.

name: Paul S. Rosenbloom
contribution: For contributions to unified theories of cognition, and to integrated architectures for intelligence; and for service to the AI community.

name: Stuart C. Shapiro
affiliation: State University of New York at Buffalo
contribution: For contributions to theory and practice of knowledge representation and reasoning, and service to the AI community.

name: Judith B. Bachant
contribution: For superior engineering accomplishments in embedding expert configuration systems in Digital’s business processes.

name: Robert Balzer
affiliation: University of Southern California Information Sciences Institute
contribution: For contributions to automatic programming and rule-based development environments through the development of Gist, FSD, and the transformation based Rederivation Lifecycle.

name: Margaret A. Boden
contribution: For contributions to the philosophy of AI, links between AI and psychology, social implications of AI, and making AI accessible to non-specialists.

name: Paul R. Cohen
contribution: For leadership in the development of experimental methodologies for AI research, important contributions to real-time planning, and uncertainty management in expert systems.

name: Peter Friedland
contribution: For pioneering work in planning, KR languages, scientific discovery, AI applications to molecular biology; and for extraordinary leadership and service.

name: Cordell C. Green
contribution: For the development of the foundation theory for logic programming, the deductive data base field, and many formal-inference-based AI systems; and for his seminal contributions to the field of program synthesis.

name: Joseph Y. Halpern
contribution: For sustained excellence in theoretical research on the logics of and relationships among knowledge, common knowledge, belief and probability.

name: David Haussler
contribution: For scientific contributions to the theory and practice of machine learning.

name: Ellen Hildreth
contribution: For contributions to artificial intelligence in the fields of motion vision and natural computation.

name: Ramesh Jain
contribution: For pioneering and sustained contributions to computer vision research and applications.

name: Jean-Claude Latombe
contribution: For contributions to robotics, particularly the theory and practice of robot motion planning.

name: Donald W. Loveland
contribution: For outstanding contributions to the field of automated reasoning and development of the model elimination theorem-proving procedure.

name: John Mylopoulos
contribution: For outstanding leadership in Canadian AI; foundational roles in the oldest AI society; and superior productivity in education and research.

name: Ramesh Patil
affiliation: University of Southern California Information Sciences Institute
contribution: For seminal contributions in medical AI, diagnostic reasoning, and knowledge representation; and for service to AAAI.

name: Christopher K. Riesbeck
contribution: For pioneering contributions to natural language analysis by computer, and for the development and codification of case-based reasoning.

name: Lenhart K. Schubert
contribution: For fundamental contributions in natural language processing, especially in the formalization, representation, and practical implementation of non-first order concepts.

name: John F. Sowa
affiliation: State University of New York at Binghamton
contribution: For his outstanding contributions on the theory of conceptual graphs for knowledge representation and reasoning, and for his leadership in inspiring and directing the world-wide efforts of other researchers and students in advancing this theory.

name: Mark J. Steedman
contribution: For contributions to the integration of syntax, semantics, and prosody in human language processing, using the framework of categorial grammars.

name: Austin Tate
contribution: For contributions to the development and use of knowledge-based planning techniques and artificial intelligence technology transfer.

name: Richmond H. Thomason
contribution: For fundamental contributions to the logical foundations of artificial intelligence and computational linguistics.

name: Wolfgang Wahlster
contribution: For pioneering work in the development of dialog systems, and outstanding service to the artificial intelligence community.

name: Sholom M. Weiss
contribution: For pioneering contributions to practical systems for causal and expert reasoning, and machine learning, especially in biomedicine.

name: William L. Whittaker
contribution: For contributions to robotics education, and research and development of field robotics.

name: Narendra Ahuja
contribution: For significant contributions to the integration of multiple cues for three-dimensional and active vision; object representation and path planning; and multiprocessor architectures for computer vision.

name: Michael Anthony Arbib
contribution: For his work in schema theory and neural networks to provide a linking methodology between distributed artificial intelligence and brain theory.

name: William J. Clancey
affiliation: Institute for Human & Machine Cognition and NASA/Ames Research Center
contribution: For his influential knowledge analyses of expert systems and pioneering work in grounding AI research in scientific and engineering modeling.

name: Philip R. Cohen
contribution: For seminal work in the plan-based application of speech acts, and continued excellence in the study of natural language discourse.

name: Gerald Francis DeJong III
contribution: For seminal technical contributions to natural language processing and machine learning, as well as excellence in teaching future researchers.

name: Lee D. Erman
contribution: For contributions to the development and dissemination of AI Technology and service to AAAI.

name: Kenneth D. Forbus
contribution: For contributions to qualitative physics, cognitive modeling, reasoning engine design and machine learning, and general service to the AI community.

name: Frederick Hayes-Roth
contribution: For leadership in commercialization of expert system technology; for the co-development of Hearsay II and opportunistic-planning; and for the technical management of ROSIE, M.1, S.1, and ABE.

name: Jerry Robert Hobbs
contribution: For research in artificial intelligence, particularly natural language understanding and knowledge representation.

name: Laveen N. Kanal
affiliation: University of Maryland and L. N. K. Corporation
contribution: For contributions to pattern recognition and heuristic search procedures and their application in the machine recognition of patterns.

name: Janet L. Kolodner
contribution: For pioneering research on case-based reasoning and learning, including memory organization, information retrieval, problem solving, and knowledge acquisition.

name: Benjamin J. Kuipers
contribution: For fundamental contributions to qualitative reasoning about physical systems (QSIM) and qualitative methods for robot exploration and cognitive mapping.

name: Mitchell P. Marcus
contribution: For work in novel parsing architectures for integrating syntax, semantics, and psycholinguistic phenomena, and the development of learning techniques based on large corpora.

name: Matthew T. Mason
contribution: For lasting contributions to robotic manipulation in the areas of compliant force control, planning under uncertainty, the mechanics of pushing, and sensorless manipulation strategies.

name: Ramakant Nevatia
contribution: For pioneering contributions to many aspects of computer vision, especially in computational descriptions of complex three-dimensional objects.

name: Glenn R. Shafer
contribution: For the development of the Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence and its applications to AI systems.

name: Howard E. Shrobe
contribution: For significant contributions in the development of new problem solving approaches and programming languages, and for service to the field.

name: William R. Swartout
affiliation: University of Southern California Information Sciences Institute
contribution: For seminal contributions in the areas of knowledge-based machine explanation, and for extraordinary service to the Artificial Intelligence community.

name: Peter Szolovits
contribution: For pioneering the application of Artificial Intelligence in Medicine.

name: Leslie G. Valiant
contribution: For the development of computational learning theory, and providing a scientific basis for research in machine learning.

name: Robert A. Kowalski
affiliation: Imperial College of Science and Technology

name: Yorick A. Wilks
affiliation: “Institute for Human and Machine Cognition / New Mexico State University

name: James F. Allen
affiliation: University of Rochester and Institute for Human and Machine Cognition
